message: "I started backing away, keeping my eyes on it. Today’s pupils should go into the world with a knowledge of their history and geography, their environment, the working of their bodies, the upbringing of children, law, money, the economy and civil rights.

media.alt: For the last eight years, Gift and her husband Abu have spent most of their married life on the road fighting FGM in south-east Nigeria

message: In Ugep, a village in Nigeria, there is a large tree that towers over the children standing next to it. Around its trunk are ribbons of cloth used to tie young girls who had reached puberty, in preparation for their clitoris and labia to be cut off in the public square as part of a ritual to symbolise their entry into womanhood. Gift Abu and her husband have spent the past 8 years working to end this practice.

message: "Street harassment, misogyny and racism are a daily occurrence for black women in this country. If we are not on the receiving end of those then we are treated as if we are invisible. attachment.description: Some of the most beautiful walks in England and Wales will be appearing on Google Street View from 17 March. Here we meet the ‘cyborg’ rangers capturing the stunning scenery for a global audience

media.alt: Some of the most beautiful walks in England and Wales will be appearing on Google Street View from 17 March. Here we meet the ‘cyborg’ rangers capturing the stunning scenery for a global audience

message: There is no book, no starring role by Reese Witherspoon and no Nick Hornby screenplay – as there was for Wild – to promote the 15 national trails of England and Wales. There is, instead, a project for rangers and volunteers to take on the role of “cyborgs” by carrying futuristic equipment that will showcase the spectacular scenery of the trails on computers around the world.

attachment.name: Muhammad Ali: rebel, showman and the lord of the ring

media.alt: This week, an exhibition opens in London that honours the man whose charm, wit and courage, not to mention astonishing boxing skills, made him the greatest sportsman of the 20th century

message: When it comes to sports, there are great athletes and famous athletes and then there is Muhammad Ali.

attachment.name: Will we ever really talk with the machines?
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: As the era of true artificial intelligence draws closer, the problem of a shared language rears its head

media.alt: As the era of true artificial intelligence draws closer, the problem of a shared language rears its head

message: 'How will we communicate with computers? Easy, peasy, say the AI evangelists: we’ll just talk to them just like we talk to one another. At this point, a whirring noise can be heard: it’s Ludwig Wittgenstein rotating at 5,000rpm in his grave. “What can be said at all can be said clearly,” he wrote in the Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus, “and what we cannot talk about we must pass over in silence.” And therein lies the problem. Because often what really matters to us humans is stuff that we have difficulty articulating.'

message: "You cannot save your children from their fate, but the thought of what that fate might entail sends shivers down parents’ spines. It’s a brave thing, loving another person."

attachment.name: Conor McGregor paid heavily for his hubris against Nate Diaz

attachment.description: The Irishman made a grave mistake fighting far above his natural weight division at UFC 196. But he became far more likeable in defeat

media.alt: The Irishman made a grave mistake fighting far above his natural weight division at UFC 196. But he became far more likeable in defeat

message: "In defeat Conor McGregor can still win. He did not slither from failure after a defeat few saw coming. Gone was the cocksure banter and the searing digs. The man who lost to Nate Diaz was graceful, humble and even optimistic. He might win badly but on Saturday he lost well."

attachment.name: The images of chimps thrilled me: do they show evidence of spirituality in the wild?
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: A ritual with rocks observed in a study in Guinea has profound implications for our relationship with the animal kingdom

media.alt: A ritual with rocks observed in a study in Guinea has profound implications for our relationship with the animal kingdom

message: "With each new discovery, the line that we have drawn between humans and animals fades. Many traits that we arrogantly assumed were uniquely human have been found in other species. We are not alone in our ability to feel joy or sorrow, mourn the loss of a loved one, act in altruistic ways, solve complex problems or hold unique personalities. But are we the only species with a sense of the sacred?"

attachment.name: Dustin Hoffman: ‘I was an outsider. I came to New York and I was cleaning toilets’
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: 'I wasn’t invited to the Oscars, I wasn’t nominated and I would never go just to go. It’s one of the worst shows in town if you’re there...'

media.alt: 'I wasn’t invited to the Oscars, I wasn’t nominated and I would never go just to go. It’s one of the worst shows in town if you’re there...'

message: Even after The Graduate made him a superstar, Dustin Hoffman always saw himself as a ‘funny looking semitic guy’ on the fringes of fame. Five decades on he talks about racism and the movies, how Tootsie made him a feminist, why he wishes he was Jack Nicholson... and who he thinks gave the best performances of all time.

attachment.name: The birth of cool: ‘Dressing well is almost part of the DNA in the black community’

media.alt: The author and professor owes her fascination with black style to her sharply dressed father, who arrived from Jamaica in the 50s. Here she talks about her book, The Birth of Cool

message: An amazing new celebration of black style, from Billie Holiday to Malcolm X.

attachment.name: How a CIA spy went rogue to court the world’s worst dictators
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: The remarkable tale of Frank Terpil, former intelligence agent, fugitive from US justice and a 53-year jail term, who has died in Havana

media.alt: The remarkable tale of Frank Terpil, former intelligence agent, fugitive from US justice and a 53-year jail term, who has died in Havana

message: "To those not in the know, he would introduce himself as Robert Hunt. But Robert Hunt wasn’t really Robert Hunt at all. He was Frank Terpil, rogue CIA agent. A man described as a “maniac” by the undercover US policeman who helped convict him in New York in 1981 on charges of seeking to sell 10,000 machine-guns and 20 tonnes of plastic explosives to Libya. A coldly intelligent, no-scruples dealmaker, and confidant of the later 20th century’s most brutal dictators, from the Shah of Iran to Idi Amin."

attachment.name: From Trump to Merkel: how the world is divided between fear and openness
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: The Republican candidate and German chancellor are polar opposites in the key struggle of our age

media.alt: The Republican candidate and German chancellor are polar opposites in the key struggle of our age

message: "Territorialists like Donald J. Trump suggest that people can have their cake and eat it: disrupt globalisation and stay rich, minimise investment in international affairs and remain safe and free. They take the huge gains in prosperity, security and freedom of the last decades for granted. They fail to understand that those gains depend on massive investments of nation states in international order, and that globalisation is based on open societies and increasingly easy cross-border flows of goods, people and information."

attachment.name: Mother’s Day is about love, not how hot you look
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Why has such a cherished occasion been so debased by commercial vulgarity?

media.alt: Why has such a cherished occasion been so debased by commercial vulgarity?

message: 'How delightful that there are now bad taste Mother’s Day cards. There are jibes about rubbish cooking, bad driving and general maternal incompetence. Have I missed something? Is Nuts magazine still going and now sponsoring Mother’s Day? Or is this just another reminder that however fulfilling, not to mention difficult and knackering a woman might think the role of mother is, it’s never going to matter more than how “HOT!” she is?"'

attachment.name: The ugly truth about body dysmorphia
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Some children see only things to hate about the way they look. Their condition can lead to depression, anxiety, self-surgery and even suicide, reports Eva Wiseman

media.alt: Some children see only things to hate about the way they look. Their condition can lead to depression, anxiety, self-surgery and even suicide, reports Eva Wiseman

message: "A man took a razor blade and very carefully cut open his nose. His aim was to remove the cartilage and replace it with that of a chicken. Finally, he’d feel so much better. A man took a hammer to his face. Somebody cut the ends of their fingers off. Across the world people are standing in bathrooms with knives, quietly hating themselves. Self-surgery is one of the hallmarks of body dysmorphic disorder, where a person has a distorted view of how they look. A nose, a hand. A place to focus on, and to hate."

attachment.name: Jess Phillips: someone to believe in

attachment.description: In the six months since she became an MP, the plain-speaking Phillips has made quite a lot of noise – not for her the anonymity of the back benches...

attachment.name: Gimme shelter: stories from London’s homeless

attachment.description: There are more rough sleepers in the London borough of Westminster than anywhere else in the UK. We hear their stories…

media.alt: There are more rough sleepers in the London borough of Westminster than anywhere else in the UK. We hear their stories…

message: "Perhaps the most striking aspect of these interviews is the sheer variety of testimonies we encountered. No two stories are similar, and there seems to be no predictable or formulaic path from a comfortable home to a life on the streets. There are as many ways of becoming homeless as there are homeless people, in other words, and almost no one is immune."

This report’s answer can be summed up in one word: fail."

media.alt: Behaviour-recording program tracks a child’s education, but ensuring privacy is a concern

But now honesty may be the only option as behaviour-tracking apps are becoming increasingly popular as an educational tool."

attachment.name: My mother before I knew her
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Inspired by Carol Ann Duffy’s poem Before You Were Mine, writers reflect on photographs of their mothers before they were born

media.alt: Inspired by Carol Ann Duffy’s poem Before You Were Mine, writers reflect on photographs of their mothers before they were born

message:
"Pointless as it may be, I wish this woman, whom I have never met, a better future life, if only as the mother of the daughter she never had. In fact, I wish she hadn’t turned out to be my mother – though, in a way, more for her sake than for mine."

Major writers, from Jeanette Winterson to Julia Donaldson, from William Boyd to Julian Barnes, reflect on photographs of their mothers taken before they were born.

attachment.name: Sylvia Pankhurst: shunned, snubbed, now to be honoured at last
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: The suffragette’s socialist ideals caused a rift with her mother and sister

media.alt: The suffragette’s socialist ideals caused a rift with her mother and sister

message: "The proposed statue of Sylvia has always been rejected. The reason was that she did not fit in with the establishment of the time by opposing the war. And she was a socialist and an anti-racist campaigner. This statue will correct the historical record.”

attachment.name: Harry Potter role-playing at real-life Hogwarts
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: At College of Wizardry at Czocha Castle in Poland, Katie Forster re-creates the magical world of Harry Potter – the unofficial version, that is

media.alt: At College of Wizardry at Czocha Castle in Poland, Katie Forster re-creates the magical world of Harry Potter – the unofficial version, that is

message: "My friends think I’ve gone to a role-playing sex party. They’ve heard I’m spending the weekend at a Polish castle dressed as a schoolgirl wizard with more than 100 strangers. We’re going to put hexes on each other and sleep in mixed dormitories. I know how it sounds. But the College of Wizardry is a Larp, which stands for live-action role play. There are 140 “players” from 29 countries, joining an unofficial re-creation of J.K. Rowling's magical world of Harry Potter."

attachment.name: Of all the things we can blame on the Premier League, child sex abuse is not one
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Adam Johnson’s crime was not the fault of his sport, which has become the scapegoat for society’s ills

media.alt: Adam Johnson’s crime was not the fault of his sport, which has become the scapegoat for society’s ills

message: "Many are glossing this case of child sex abuse with the exact same cliches they might slap on a grasping contract negotiation or a particularly baroque Bentley customisation. Sense of entitlement, pampered prima donna, consequence-free environment – is it really all the same? No. No, it isn’t. Of all the things that are the fault of the Premier League (and heaven knows I’ve spent enough years detailing them) child sexual abuse is not one of them."

attachment.name: Russia ‘stoking refugee unrest in Germany to topple Angela Merkel’

message: “Russia is establishing a network that can be controlled. You can use it as they have tried to do in Germany, combined with the legitimate issue of refugees, to undercut political processes in a very serious way."

attachment.name: 'Your whole life is the Holocaust!' The woman who was born in Auschwitz
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Angela Orosz gave evidence in the trial of a Nazi guard: ‘I was so malnourished, I was unable to cry. That saved me.’

media.alt: Angela Orosz gave evidence in the trial of a Nazi guard: ‘I was so malnourished, I was unable to cry. That saved me.’

message: She was born on the top bunk in the barracks of camp C at Auschwitz-Birkenau in December 1944. She had weighed just 1kg and was too weak to cry. Sixty years later she finally broke her silence. Last week she took one of her most courageous decisions yet, to take to the witness stand in the case of a 94-year-old former SS guard, in what will be one of the last from the Nazi concentration camps. The incredible story of Angela Orosz.

attachment.name: Things I’ve learned in time for my first Mother’s Day
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: As a new mother, the past year has been full of life lessons for Eva. Here she reveals five of them

media.alt: As a new mother, the past year has been full of life lessons for Eva. Here she reveals five of them

message: "I had no idea I’d ever want time by myself. Myself is boring. But today I crave it like cigarettes. Yet any snatched moments alone are so precious and rare that they often go wasted - I stand in the kitchen, crippled by possibility. Much as I adore my tiny daughter, with a hard and wounding love, the best Mother’s Day gift she could give me is an afternoon without her."

message: One headhunter said: “I think there are an awful lot of FTSE 100 CEOs who are pretty mediocre.” Another added: “I think that the wage drift over the past 10 years, or the salary drift, has been inexcusable, incomprehensible, and it is very serious for the social fabric of the country.”

attachment.name: George Osborne would fail his economics GCSE

attachment.name: Taking mum to the movies on Mother’s Day? Don’t see these
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: What could be better than taking your beloved mother to see a heart-warming film? Literally anything, if any of these shockers happen to be on at the cinema

media.alt: What could be better than taking your beloved mother to see a heart-warming film? Literally anything, if any of these shockers happen to be on at the cinema

message: "Nobody takes their mum to the cinema on Mother’s Day. This is because your mum only wants to spend the day doing one of two things. If you’re an adult, she wants to spend some time with you for a change. And, if you’re a child, she wants to spend some time away from you for a change. Which is probably for the best because, when it comes to films about mums, all bets are off."

attachment.name: Who would be a librarian now? You know what, I'll have a go
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: My friends laugh at me but training to be a professional librarian is a sort of calling – like becoming a priest, only with warmer business premises

media.alt: My friends laugh at me but training to be a professional librarian is a sort of calling – like becoming a priest, only with warmer business premises

message: "A successful day in the library is one where people complain, like they would with any other local authority service. The Wi-Fi isn’t good enough; there aren’t enough academic texts; it’s too cold; it’s too loud; why don’t you have this book? I love it. Complain and moan all you like – it’s your library service. It’s for you: take it, have it, use it. I’m your public librarian and this is your public library, and these are the hallmarks of public service."

attachment.name: James Rebanks: ‘Sheep are fast. For 500 you’d need 200 shepherds’

media.alt: The letter you always wanted to write

I feel so lucky to have loved and been loved by such a person. My time with you taught me not only to embrace life, but also how to be a wife and a mother."

attachment.name: Bad blood: the taboo on talking about periods is damaging lives
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: We have 5,000 euphemisms for menstruation, but we still can’t talk about them openly – and stop the stigma that’s harming women’s health and education

media.alt: We have 5,000 euphemisms for menstruation, but we still can’t talk about them openly – and stop the stigma that’s harming women’s health and education

message: "Whatever it takes to bring periods out of the realm of secret and hidden is fine with me. But euphemisms are fine with me too. It would be nice if we were capable of talking more clearly about our bodies. But what’s damaging the lives of millions is not daft and coy terms for periods, but being unable to talk about them at all, or being so ashamed that they have to dry their sanitary cloths under the beds or in the damp, getting urinary infections or worse."

message:
"Michael Gove and Boris Johnson have been posing in purple, clutching litter-picking equipment, to publicise Clean for the Queen.

Not that I disapprove of tidying up our filthy, stinking streets, and I sympathise with this latest effort to do so by Keep Britain Tidy, but even though litter has increased 500% since the 60s, I would stoically wade forever through streets knee-deep in dreck, rather than do as I’m told by those two pompous twerps."

message: "My 12th birthday was met with “hilarious” comments from friends about how really I was only three, a joke that still continues today. I’ve lost count of the childish birthday cards I’ve received on leap-year birthdays with garish badges proclaiming an age that’s only a quarter of the one I’m actually turning. On non-leap years, friends would often simply forget my birthday, or more cruelly, revel in telling me I didn’t have one."

message: After they finished shooting a disembowelment, Greg Nicotero drove home covered in blood. “Every stop sign we pulled up at, I looked over at the driver in the next car. Freaked everybody out! God, I love my job.”

attachment.name: Move to Kings Place
attachment.caption: Move to Kings Place
attachment.description: Guardian News & Media moves to its new home at Kings Place

attachment.name: Digital archive
attachment.caption: Digital archive
attachment.description: The Guardian and Observer digital archive is launched, the first example of a national UK newspaper making its paper archive available online via its website.

attachment.name: Berliner
attachment.caption: Berliner
attachment.description: The new Berliner Guardian launches, with a ground-breaking design in a mid-size format. The Guardian becomes the UK's first full-colour national newspaper, and the first UK national newspaper ever to adopt this size.

attachment.name: The newsroom
attachment.caption: The newsroom
attachment.description: The Newsroom, Guardian and Observer Archive and Visitor Centre, opens its doors. The centre preserves and promotes the histories and values of the newspapers through its archive, educational programmes and exhibitions. The Newsroom's activities all transfer to Kings Place in 2008.

media.alt: The Newsroom, Guardian and Observer Archive and Visitor Centre, opens its doors. The centre preserves and promotes the histories and values of the newspapers through its archive, educational programmes and exhibitions. The Newsroom's activities all transfer to Kings Place in 2008.

attachment.description: The Guardian wins widespread acclaim for its coverage of the events of 11 September proclaimed "bold, simple and courageous" at the British Press Awards.

attachment.name: Welcome to the webz: Guardian unlimited
attachment.caption: Welcome to the webz: Guardian unlimited
attachment.description: Guardian Unlimited network of websites is launched in January 1999 and quickly becomes one of the UK's most popular newspaper websites, growing dramatically over the following years. Guardian Unlimited is renamed guardian.co.uk in 2008.

attachment.name: Remembering Princess Diana
attachment.caption: Remembering Princess Diana
attachment.description: A special Saturday edition of the Observer to mark the death of Princess Diana on 31 August 1997

attachment.name: 'A liar and a cheat'
attachment.caption: 'A liar and a cheat'
attachment.description: The Guardian's investigation into conservative MP Neil Hamilton wins the Team Reporting Award at the British Press Awards and the Guardian is named Newspaper of the Year by What the Papers Say, an award it also wins in 1998 and 1999.

attachment.name: Alan Rusbridger becomes editor
attachment.caption: Alan Rusbridger becomes editor
attachment.description: Alan Rusbridger becomes editor. He is still currently editor-in-chief.

attachment.name: Guardian Media Group acquires the Observer
attachment.caption: Guardian Media Group acquires the Observer
attachment.description:
Faced with the acquisition of a natural ally by a major competitor, the Guardian Media Group acquired the Observer in 1993. As a result the Observer has been able to maintain its editorial independence, ensuring the continuation of the paper's long-standing tradition of liberal politics and independent journalism.

The Observer has continued its reputation for setting, rather than following the news agenda, breaking stories including exposing the cash-for-access scandal dubbed Lobbygate, and leading the way in covering of issues like GM foods and cloning.

attachment.name: Redesign and Guardian Weekend
attachment.caption: Redesign and Guardian Weekend
attachment.description: The Guardian has a radical redesign, splitting the newspaper into two sections and introducing a new masthead. An international edition is launched in Europe and the Weekend section is published for the first time.

attachment.name: Sarah Tisdall case
attachment.caption: Sarah Tisdall case
attachment.description: A Foreign and Commonwealth Office clerical officer gives the Guardian documents on the movement of nuclear weapons. The Guardian is taken to court and ordered to reveal their source and Sarah Tisdall is imprisoned for six months.

attachment.name: 119 Farringdon Road
attachment.caption: 119 Farringdon Road
attachment.description: The Guardian moves from Gray's Inn Road to its own offices at 119 Farringdon Road, which are to be home to the paper for the next 32 years.

attachment.name: Peter Preston appointed editor
attachment.caption: Peter Preston appointed editor
attachment.description: Peter Preston is appointed editor, a post he is to hold for 20 years.

attachment.name: New home at Cross Street
attachment.caption: New home at Cross Street
attachment.description: On 29 August the Guardian's Manchester office moves from its home in Cross Street to new offices in nearby Deansgate. The Guardian had been written and printed from this office since 1886.

attachment.name: Inside Cross Street
attachment.caption: Inside Cross Street
attachment.description: The subeditors' room at Cross Street

attachment.name: Inside Cross Street
attachment.caption: Inside Cross Street
attachment.description: This picture was taken between 1969 and 1970 and shows the Subeditors room at Cross Street

attachment.name: Move from Manchester to London
attachment.caption: Move from Manchester to London
attachment.description: The editor's office and major editorial departments relocate from Manchester to London. The London office is in Gray's Inn Road where the Guardian has been printing since 1961, and is shared with The Sunday Times.

attachment.name: JFK assassinated
attachment.caption: JFK assassinated
attachment.description: Front page of the Guardian after the shooting of US president John F Kennedy

attachment.name: Man on the moon
attachment.caption: Man on the moon
attachment.description: How the Guardian reported the moon landing

attachment.name: Printing in London: 'The Graun' is born
attachment.caption: Printing in London: 'The Graun' is born
attachment.description: To enable swifter delivery of the Guardian to southern England the newspaper begins printing in London as well as Manchester on 11 September 1961. Difficulties with the printing system earn the newspaper the nickname 'The Grauniad'.

attachment.name: Manchester Guardian becomes the Guardian
attachment.caption: Manchester Guardian becomes the Guardian
attachment.description: On 24 August 1959 the newspaper changes its title from the Manchester Guardian to the Guardian, to reflect the growing importance of national and international affairs in the newspaper.

attachment.name: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.caption: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.description: More images from the subs room

attachment.name: In the sub's room
attachment.caption: In the sub's room
attachment.description:
Here's an image of the Manchester Guardian subeditors' room

Photograph: Adolf Morath
Manchester Guardian

attachment.name: Suez crisis
attachment.caption: Suez crisis
attachment.description: Alastair Hetherington becomes editor following Wadsworth's death. He is strongly against the government's military action in Suez and in contrast to the majority of the British press the Guardian is consistently critical of the invasion.

attachment.name: Death of King George VI
attachment.caption: Death of King George VI
attachment.description: The front page of the Manchester Guardian after the death of King George VI

attachment.name: News on the front page
attachment.caption: News on the front page
attachment.description: On WP Crozier's death, Alfred Powell Wadsworth become editor. During his editorship the Manchester Guardian puts news on the front page in place of classified ads for the first time, and circulation more than doubles to over 168,000 copies a day.

attachment.name: Edward's abdication
attachment.caption: Edward's abdication
attachment.description: King Edward VIII renounces the throne. "The King never wavered," reports the Manchester Guardian.

attachment.name: The Scott Trust is born
attachment.caption: The Scott Trust is born
attachment.description: Ownership of the Guardian is transferred to a trust to protect the newspaper from crippling death duties following the untimely death of Ted Scott. His brother John creates the Scott Trust to ensure the independence of the newspaper and the continuance of the journalistic principles of his father, CP Scott.

attachment.name: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.caption: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.description: This is the stereo department

attachment.name: WP Crozier
attachment.caption: WP Crozier
attachment.description: CP Scott dies in January 1932, followed only three months later by his son Ted Scott who is killed in a tragic boating accident. William Perceival Crozier is appointed as editor in place of Ted Scott, a position he is to hold until his death in 1944.

attachment.name: Ted Scott takes over as editor
attachment.caption: Ted Scott takes over as editor
attachment.description: CP Scott retires after 57 years as editor, and his son Edward (Ted) Scott takes over. Ted joined the Manchester Guardian in 1913, and had already made his mark as labour correspondence and a leader writer before taking on the editorship in 1929.

attachment.name: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.caption: Inside Manchester Guardian

attachment.name: An advert for the Guardian's centenary issue in 1921
attachment.caption: An advert for the Guardian's centenary issue in 1921

attachment.name: First Guardian weekly
attachment.caption: First Guardian weekly
attachment.description: On 4 July 1919 Guardian Weekly is launched to provide a compact weekly edition of the newspaper

attachment.name: The Amazing Truce: Christmas in the trenches
attachment.caption: The Amazing Truce: Christmas in the trenches
attachment.description: The Guardian reports on an unlikely truce in the trenches: "'On Christmas Eve both troops were singing to one another, and on Christmas morning after some shouted conversation across the open space between the trenches a German shouted: "Be British and come half-way!" and out goes one of our officers.'"

attachment.name: Walter Doughty
attachment.caption: Walter Doughty
attachment.description: Walter Doughty is appointed as the Guardian's first staff photographer, reflecting the growing importance of photography in newspapers. An innovative  and talented photojournalist he is to work for the paper until his death in the 1950s.

attachment.name: CP Scott becomes both owner and editor
attachment.caption: CP Scott becomes both owner and editor
attachment.description: Following the death of John Edward Taylor's son in 1905 CP Scott buys the Guardian. He is both owner and editor
